questoesMultiplaEscolha.enunciado: Choose this, that, these, those to complete the following sentences.

exercicios.questao: 'What's _____?' 'It's a calculator.'
exercicios.explicacao: Calculator is singular, and we use this or that for singular.

exercicios.questao: ______ are John and Teresa.
exercicios.explicacao: John and Theresa is plural, and we use these or those for plural.

exercicios.questao: Hi, Richard, _____ is Julia. (On the phone)
exercicios.explicacao: We use this is when we introduce people and on the telephone.

exercicios.questao: Look at _____ cloud. It's very strange.
exercicios.explicacao: Clouds are not near; they are in the sky. We use that or those for things that are not near.

exercicios.questao: 'What are _____?' 'They are little cakes.'
exercicios.explicacao: Cakes is plural, and we use these or those for plural.

exercicios.questao: _____ are my keys.
exercicios.explicacao: Keys is plural, and we use these or those for plural.

exercicios.questao: Is _____ your mother?
exercicios.explicacao: Mother is singular, and we use this or that for singular.

exercicios.questao: What is in _____ box over there?
exercicios.explicacao: Over there means 'not near' (not here), and we use that or those for things that are not near.

exercicios.questao: _____ is my hand!
exercicios.explicacao: My hand is here, and we use this or these for things that are here (near).

exercicios.questao: _____ are my cats.
exercicios.explicacao: Cats is plural, and we use these or those for plural.

questoesDialogo.titulo: Future forms – will, be going to, present continuous
questoesDialogo.enunciado: Complete the dialogue with the most suitable future forms: present continuous, be going to, will, or shall.

inputs.resposta: are you doing/are you going to do
inputs.explicacao:
We use the present continuous to talk or ask about future arrangements, i.e. future actions that are already planned or decided.
We can also use be going to for plans and intentions.
We use shall I or shall we to make offers and suggestions.

dialogos.fala: Rosa: Not this evening. I  (input3)  (work) on a project until late.

inputs.explicacao: We use be going to for plans and intentions (decisions that have been already made).

dialogos.fala: Maria: And when do you think you  (input4)  (be) free for a drink?

inputs.explicacao: We use will to predict future events that we think will happen.

dialogos.fala: Rosa: I don't know. I have my diary here with me; let me see. What about tomorrow?  (input5)  (you/do) anything?

inputs.resposta: Are you doing/Are you going to do
inputs.explicacao:
We use the present continuous to talk or ask about future arrangements, i.e. future actions that are already planned or decided.
We can also use be going to for plans and intentions.

dialogos.fala: Maria: I  (input6)  (see) my dentist tomorrow. Is Thursday OK?

inputs.explicacao:
The verb see has a dynamic and a static sense. It is dynamic when it means ‘meet’, ‘have an appointment’, or ‘have a relationship with someone’.
We use the present continuous to talk or ask about future arrangements, i.e. future actions that are already planned or decided.
We use shall I or shall we to make offers and suggestions.

dialogos.fala: Rosa: I  (input8)  (meet) a friend at 6. Is 7 OK?

inputs.explicacao: We use the present continuous to talk or ask about future arrangements, i.e. future actions that are already planned or decided.

dialogos.fala: Maria: Yes, great. But I don't have my car.
Rosa: Don't worry, I  (input9)  (take) mine.  (input10)  (I/pick you up) at 7 then?

inputs.explicacao: We use will to express instant decisions (decisions that we make at the moment of speaking).
We use shall I or shall we to make offers and suggestions.
